column1: Two major highways pass through and have interchanges in Greenbelt: the Capital Beltway (I-95/I-495) and the National Park Service's owned and maintained portion of the Baltimore–Washington Parkway (unsigned MD 295).  The Greenbelt portion of the Baltimore–Washington Parkway (B–W Parkway) is part of the parkway's 19-mile section which was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1991.Additionally
column2: Greenbelt Road is part of state highway MD 193
column3: which connects several suburban communities in both Prince George's and Montgomery counties. Kenilworth Avenue (MD 201) traverses Greenbelt in a north–south direction
column4: running parallel to the B–W Parkway
column5: providing an alternate travel route into Washington
column7: from Greenbelt.  The southernmost Maryland portion of Kenilworth Avenue forms a major interchange with both the B–W Parkway and US 50 near the Maryland–D.C. line

column3: as a public cooperative community in the New Deal era.  The concept was at the same time both eminently practical and idealistically utopian: the federal government would foster an "ideal" self-sufficient cooperative community that would also ease the pressing housing shortage near the nation's capital. Construction of the new town would also create jobs and thus help stimulate the national economic recovery following the Great Depression.

column2: which provided affordable housing for federal government workers

Much of the federal government planned and developed portion of the city is located within the Greenbelt Historic District.

column1: The City of Greenbelt operates under a council-manager government as established by the city charter
column2: the first such arrangement in Maryland.  The Council consists of seven members elected by plurality-at-large voting. From their members
column3: the Council selects the Mayor and the Mayor Pro Tem (who assumes the duties of the Mayor when the Mayor is unavailable). The Council has traditionally chosen the member with the highest vote count to be Mayor and the member with the second-highest vote count as Mayor Pro Tem.  Elections are held every two years
column5: in part to diminish the influence of political parties. Political party affiliations are not an official part of the city election process and are seldom part of candidate campaigns. Regular council meetings are held on Mondays
column6: twice per month except during July
column9: when meetings are held once per month.The City Council is supported by 14 advisory boards and committees of citizen volunteers.  The council appoints a professional city manager responsible for supervising government operations and implementing the policies adopted by the council.

column1: Of the ten incorporated cities in Prince George's County
column2: Greenbelt is one of three with at-large elections for council and mayor. (The others are District Heights and New Carrollton.)  The remaining seven use combinations of districts and at-large voting.  On 2008-02-28
column3: the Maryland American Civil Liberties Union and Prince George's County NAACP sent a letter to the Greenbelt City Council claiming that Greenbelt's at-large system may violate section 2 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. According to the letter
column4: the 2000 Census indicated that African-Americans constituted 38% of Greenbelt's voting-age population
column5: Asians 13%
column8: all members of the city council were white. The letter proposed that the city switch to single-winner district-based voting
column11: and indicated a lawsuit would follow if no reform were implemented. While the city population is racially diverse
column12: only two African Americans had run for Council in the 30 years preceding the 2009 election
column13: one of whom had withdrawn before the election. In June 2008
column14: the United States Department of Justice opened an investigation into the city's election system.In 2008
column15: the city government hosted three public community meetings regarding election reform
column18: and FairVote. Over 100 residents attended the forums
column19: including one of the unsuccessful African American candidates

column2: who said
column3: "My concern is that people don’t get off their royal behinds. By going to meetings I got what I wanted and found out I had power as a citizen."In 2009
column4: the city implemented several election reforms with the goal of increasing diversity: increasing the city council from five to seven members
column5: adding another precinct in Greenbelt East to shorten voter lines
column6: and amending the city charter to allow early voting.In the election held November 3
column11: electing him to the Council as Mayor Pro Tem
column12: the second-highest city official.  Voter turnout increased from 1
column14: 399 voters (a 26% increase in ballots cast) from 2007 to 2009.In the election held November 5
column16: Emmett Jordan was chosen by 77% of voters
column17: and receiving highest vote count was then elected Mayor by the council.

column1: The United States Department of the Interior's National Park Service manages and operates Greenbelt Park.
The United States Postal Service operates the Greenbelt Post Office.
The federally planned and constructed inner core of the city was designated as the Greenbelt Historic District by the Maryland Historical Trust
column2: and subsequently placed on the National Park Service's maintained National Register of Historic Places on November 25
column3: 1980.  The historic district's status was elevated to  National Historic Landmark District status on February 18
column4: 1997.  The district contains Roosevelt Center (originally named simply The Center
column5: and later renamed in honor of President Roosevelt) and many buildings in the Art Deco style.  Roosevelt Center contains the Greenbelt Co-op Supermarket and Pharmacy (the Co-op)
column9: while also adding the Greenbelt Arts Center (located underneath the Co-op
column10: in what was previously the city's bowling alley)
column11: and additional new businesses such as the New Deal Cafe
column12: with its name honoring the origins of its location.  Both the Co-op and the New Deal Cafe carry on a tradition from the city's inception
column13: as they operate as non-profit cooperative membership corporations.
